pros: I enjoyed this position immensely, if I still lived in Madison, Wisconsin I would more than likely still be with them. The clients and my director were great.
cons: Hard to find good quality staff that will actually work and be a good influence on the client.

pros: Residents are friendly. Other coworkers were nice
cons: Management will leave you at a one of the group homes for over 12 hours without communication. Hired people but usually they would never show

pros: great atmosphere in the office
cons: salary is not the best

job_title: Linrary Technician in Voorhees Corner, NJ
pros: Good benefits and good working conditions
cons: None great place to work

review_title: If you stay it will be for and because of the clients.
job_title: Residential Coordinator in Wisconsin Rapids, WI
pros: Every day you work with some pretty amazing individuals who make the job rewarding. The clients are the shining star of this job and I never had a day were I didn't smile because of something they said, did, or how they made me feel while helping them. Bad days turn around quickly in my experience as every client had more character to be forgiving than most people. I never would have stayed as long as I did had it not been for the clients. Plus "little" wins were rewarding for both your and the person you were helping.
cons:
LOW pay. The pay would be a bit more acceptable if one did not need health insurance. Combined with health insurance and 80 hour paycheck had the take home pay of $350 - $400 after employee contributions. They had changed their 24 hour weekend shifts to pay the worker only for their day work and the times they woke up at night so an example shift would be from 5 pm Friday to 5 pm Saturday and would pay you for 16 hours of work plus your few wakeups. From what I understand these programs were transferred to another company who seems to be thriving with the same set up.

This was hands down the worst experience with persons in management I had ever known in my 20+ years of work history in several vocations. HR and a few managers and one director were fantastic people to work with. In other situations employees knew to keep their head down until it really mattered and that was for clients. A bad manager was nearly untouchable and complaints were ignored unless they could be harmful to the clients.

review_title: Could Be a Great Place to Work... But It's Not
pros:
-The disabled clients you work with are usually a joy to be around. Some have more severe issues than others, but all in all, they are the best part of working for this company.
-Decent training
-Most of the direct caregivers try their hardest & really do care about the clients
-Decent PTO accrual schedule (vacation, sick, holiday, birthday)
cons:
-VERY minimal rewards; in the 3+ years I was there, they gave 2% raises one time to employees... But only if they had been there for more than 2 years
-Which wasn't very many people since the turnover is so ridiculously high within this company
-Responsible for finding someone to cover your shifts if you're sick, even if you have sick time PTO accrued
-Managers are super write-up happy; they'll get a report of something an employee did wrong, write a write up, call the employee in to ream them out, THEN ask for their side of the story
-They overwork their program managers (hourly) while the program directors (salary) work 6 hour days and don't bother answering their phones when they're needed... Talking 80 hour work weeks with 16-24 hour long shifts
-Recently had a lot of programs close and at least a dozen people lost their jobs
-They treat everyone like they're replaceable (which they technically are) and very rarely truly reward the best employees; residential coordinators bend over backwards for their managers and instead of being rewarded, they're asked to bend over just a little more
-Crappy schedules for full time residential coordinators... Most companies like this offer rotating weekends, but a lot of the full time RCs are working weekend shifts every week since they need full time hours (due to being underpaid)
-Upper management is basically absent and PDs make crap up as they go along and have no one to answer to 98% of the time
-Most RCs have a set schedule, but when training classes come up, they HAVE to go to them even if they have plans or it conflicts with their schedule. Don't make someone who stayed up for a 10pm-8am shift attend a 10am-2pm training! That's just rude

review_title: Stay and do not move up.
job_title: Direct Care Staff in Gainesville, GA
pros: At CCS there was always work to be done if you don't mind not getting any raises, and no overtime pay or holiday pay.
cons: They show favoritism toward those that work in the office but if it wasn't for field staff working with clients, nobody would ever get paid but they are frowned upon.

pros: I love working with people with disabilities and my co-workers were mostly very good.  There used to be some  fun activities in the region where staff could get together.
cons: Lately things are just too weird there.  We got a letter saying that upper management left and now things seem really unstable.  Time to move on.

pros: Working one on one with residents is extremely rewarding. The idea of it holds so much meaning, and the relationships built are priceless!
cons: Pay is too low for the expectations. Poor training and support unit. Responsible for endless amounts of overtime with no ability to make plans in personal life, due to always being on-call for 1st, 2nd & 3rd shifts (you must stay awake for.

review_title: A great place to grow, learn and develop your skills!
pros: CCLS gave me opportunities to learn new skills and open the door for rewarding experiences. they value your input and truly want to see you become successful with your career path.
cons: The struggle of finding employees that have a passion to assist the residents in the communities.

pros: CCLS leadership live and breath their mission and values.  Employees are able to grow within the company if they are willing to work for it.  Clients are a delight to work with.
cons: Like any other company in the area, we are experiencing employee shortages.
